description: In ancient days, dark and alien gods ruled the characters, construction has begun on a white marble tower carved universe. Their offspring banished them and became the current with lotus flowers. The people organizing the construction pay well, pantheon of gods. Mortals know the current gods exist, but only the and the workers have no complaints about treatment. The organizers most ancient races have any recollection or memory of the previous are wealthy men, and they soon become advisors to the city rulers. As deities. Hidden in musty vaults are forgotten tomes written in lost the player characters travel and adventure, they find more of these languages that contain divine prophecies of the elder gods’ return. towers in other cities. They also begin to encounter divisive policies The current pantheon’s efforts focus on predicting the return time, such as tariffs on goods traded between towns, entry fees charged at preparing for it, and searching for a way to finally destroy the threat city gates, and laws requiring citizens to wear symbols of their faith their ancestors pose. They learn of the true nature of the universe, and of the threat discover that the towers are temples to a hostile deity, and they must posed by the elder gods. Perhaps the current gods then recruit the act to prevent the lotus cult from consuming their world. player characters to aid in preparation for the return. You could even build prestige classes around that recruitment. Mixing It Up You could divide attitudes along alignment lines, making good Hostile Deities deities benevolent, neutral deities indifferent, and evil deities Deities who take an actively hostile stance toward mortals can prove hostile. Good deities work to keep evil deities from destroying the overwhelming, particularly at low levels of play. As with other divine world, while neutral deities work to maintain a balance between attitudes, you need to decide why the gods are hostile. If mortals the two forces. Alternatively, you could make deities benevolent killed a god in ancient days, the existing immortals may still hold a toward mortals of their own alignment, hostile to those of opposed grudge. Mortal races from the Player’s Handbookmay have replaced alignments, and indifferent to others. Your deities may have multiple the gods’ chosen race as preeminent in the world. If the gods are dra- aspects or personalities divided among their domains, and each conic, lizardfolk may have once ruled the world as humans, dwarves, may behave differently. elves, gnomes, and halflings do now. While you decide that, also The gods may be indifferent, provided mortals worship them decide why the hostile gods don’t simply destroy the world. Perhaps according to the gods’ wishes and specifications, or they may be the gods need mortal worship as a source of power (unlike with benevolent. Failing to worship properly could displease the gods, benevolent gods, mortals worship hostile ones in hopes of placating eventually making them actively hostile. them). Destroying the world may unleash some threat to the gods currently imprisoned deep beneath the surface of the earth. WHY MORTALS WORSHIP DEITIES If the gods are hostile, clerics generally serve divine forces People worship the gods out of love, gratitude, or fear, depending rather than specific deities. Most paladins belong to secular orders on their alignment and the alignment of the god. Evil gods rather than divine ones. Many mortals seek alternatives to wor- receive plenty of worship, even from the common folk, just to shiping hostile deities, creating new demands for clerics. keep them appeased. The challenge you face in using hostile deities is the opposite of what you face with benevolent ones. In this case, you must justify Love why good gods are hostile. You can reverse one of the approaches to Mortals may love their gods as the creators of the world and all life benevolent gods by making good weaker or less significant than evil. on it. Gods may be the source of all the necessities of life. Alterna- In such a campaign, perhaps the good gods recently suffered a major tively, they may be the source of life’s luxuries, effectively buying defeat in the eternal struggle between good and evil. This theme or mortals’ love. Mortals choose to obey the gods’ laws with their setting can be tough for good-aligned characters because the world whole hearts and serve their patron deities because they want to. is set against them, but it sets the stage for epic adventuring as the Clerics convey worshipers’ love to their deity and share their joy player characters seek to redress the balance in favor of good. with their congregations. A hostile monotheism has few consequences or implications Worshiping a single god out of love carries the same concerns as different from a hostile pantheism. Because animistic spirits are omnipresent, a little different from worshiping a pantheon out of love. hostile animism makes life a living hell for everyone involved unless Love can make mortals do strange things. They may hide infor- they know how to generate enough good will to survive. If you’re mation that paints their beloved deity in a bad light. They may do creating a hostile animism, include ways to temporarily appease the spirits that are common knowledge in civilized areas. Mystery cults may teach effective appeasement techniques to initiates. There are many opportunities for secret or hidden knowledge in a system with hostile deities. Mortals must hide all experiments meant to protect them from the gods, for instance. Deities are more likely to destroy evidence of such experiments than to hide it, but single copies of the information may exist in far-off places. Mortals may live in fear of the gods destroying the world if pushed too far 15 YOUR GAME DEITIES IN CHAPTER 1: pqs ATTITUDES OF THE D&D DEITIES The deities of the D&D pantheon are generally benevolent but sometimes display streaks of indifference as affairs far from the Material Plane demand their attention. pqs terrible things out of jealousy and try to hide evidence of their Worshiping a single deity out of fear is more interesting than actions. description: The powers of a deity are far beyond those of ingly. Too much interference from the gods takes fun away from mortals. Deities may express their sympathy and compassion as the players. If a god can remove obstacles with a wave of his hand, pity. Less sympathetic deities may dismiss mortals as worthless or there’s no heroic effort needed on the part of the characters. The unimportant. It takes a great deal for mortals to get a deity to take DUNGEONS& DRAGONSgame is designed for a mortal level of them seriously. Combined with immortality, this attitude means play. The player characters are heroic not because of the tremen- deities tend to ignore immediate mortal concerns unless some- dous powers they might eventually accumulate, but because of thing threatens their power, portfolio, or very existence. Reward the terrible risks they take in the face of imminent death. To use players who have their characters phrase requests in terms that a deity to save characters from those risks repeatedly is to sully catch their deities’ interests. the heart of the game.
